attributes.comment:
I'd like to comment on the proposed fee increases for USCIS services to
international students. Specifically, as they relate to M-1 status vocational
students and Optional Practical Training (OPT), to which the students are entitled
at the end of their school program. Currently, the regulations state that M status
students must apply for work authorization on Form I-765 and an extension of
status on Form I-539. The fees associated with both of these forms are
scheduled to increase dramatically. However, the benefit that M status students
derive from these applications is limited. First of all, M students are allowed 4
weeks of OPT for every 4 months of study. The students at The French Culinary
Institute study for 6 months. I was informed by USCIS recently that this means
The FCI's graduates are entitled to 4 weeks of OPT (as opposed to the 6 weeks I
had thought they were entitled to). The Social Security Agency, as one of my
students recently discovered, will only issue social security numbers for work
authorization that is longer than one month. The practical outcome of these
rulings is that graduates of The FCI - and of other schools with similar time
frames - are unable to take advantage of OPT despite the fact that they are clearly
entitled to it. Additionally, USCIS offices do not seem to be clear on the
regulations regarding M status students. Several FCI graduates applied for an
extension of status on Form I-539 - as required in the Form I-765 instructions - but
were denied the extensions because, as the Service Center put it, the OPT
application automatically extends their M status so therefore they don't need to
apply for an extension. Anecdotally, however, I've heard of another Service Center
that will not approve OPT applications if they are not filed concurrently with
extension of status applications. I believe that prior to any fee increases, USCIS
needs to be clear - and make it clear to their customers and their advocates -
what the regulations concerning this particular class of students really state and
what the practical outcome of those regulations is. It seems to me that the
proposed fee increases for this class of students is an undue burden. I believe the
combined cost of the I-765 and I-539 applications will exceed $600 for a paltry 4
(6?) weeks of OPT employment authorization. I understand the need for the fee
increases on the part of USCIS, but I think that the fees should either be
increased in proportion to the ultimate benefit received (that is, raised for F status
students, who can really benefit from OPT and who don't have to apply for the
extension of status, but not for M status students), or the benefit that M students
receive should be increased proportionate to the fee increase (that is, a longer
OPT period). In any case, USCIS needs to clarify within its organization what the
rules governing M status students and their dependents are.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Elsa Ransom, The French Culinary Institute
